body: I'm experiencing the same problem. After some experimentation it appears that in our project, disabling the `typescript-eslint` plugin causes the `EMFILE: too many open files` error to disappear. This issue doesn't appear in the ESLint v8.57.0 even with plugin such as `typescript-eslint` enabled. For context, our project contains about 10,000 files.
I'll take a look. It's likely a problem with the retry package.

I can reproduce the EMFILE error, but I don't see the call stack error. It's strange because we do have a [test for this](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/b8270299abe777bb80a065d537aa1d4be74be705/tools/check-emfile-handling.js) that is running in CI, so I'm not sure why we're not getting failures there.

I tinkered around with the retry package but couldn't find an easy solution. I'll need to dig into this a bit deeper.

@nzakas with the repro i cant see the call stack error too. But in our private project we can see the call stack error. not sure why i am getting call stack error. I thought our code base has got some circular reference. but it ruled out when we can reproduce the error with empty ts/tsx files.

I suspect that typescript-eslint is probably doing additional file system calls on top of what ESLint is doing. Given that our test uses ESLint without typescript-eslint, I'm guessing that's why it's not failing. Still looking into this.
I've figured out the problem and will work on a fix.

issue.title: fix: Long retries

repository.name: retry
repository.description: A JavaScript utility for retrying async methods that reject errors

issue.body:
ESLint reported that some users were still getting EMFILE errors even with using Retry. 

The primary problem is that `#processQueue` was being called recursively, and when a lot of retries were necessary, this caused a stack overflow error.

There was another problem where a failed task was pushed to the front of the queue, allowing it to fail repeatedly while other tasks in the queue sat without being evaluated. Those tasks would then end up timing out and throwing the EMFILE error that they held.

This PR fixes both issues:

1. Ensures that `#processQueue` is always called either with `setTimeout()` or in a promise resolver
2. Failed tasks are pushed to the back of the queue to wait for another turn rather than the front.

I also added a test for fails for long retries prior to this fix. This will now be run as part of CI.



Refs https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/18977

issue.title: fix: Upgrade retry to avoid EMFILE errors

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.
